description: From Latin inēbriō, inēbriāre, from ēbrius (“drunk”).

adjectives.description: inebriate (comparative more inebriate, superlative most inebriate)

entries.meaning: A person who is intoxicated, especially one who is habitually drunk.
examples: As he walked along, the inebriate, whose gait was at first unsteady, recovered his equilibrium and required less help.

verbs.description: inebriate (third-person singular simple present inebriates, present participle inebriating, simple past and past participle inebriated)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To cause to be drunk; to intoxicate.
(transitive, figurative) To disorder the senses of; to exhilarate, elate or stupefy as if by spirituous drink.
examples: the inebriating effect of popular applause
fish that come from the Euxine Sea ; that when they come into the fresh water , do inebriate and turn up their bellies , so as you may take them with your hand
